posts.post_content: I love Silvos. First and most relevantly, he is a relatively cheap immense trampling beatstick that is hard to get rid of (![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) isn't going to break the bank), but secondly, the flavour is hilarious. Most pit fighters are human, but imagine you have to fight *this* in the pits.

posts.post_content:
For those who don't know, this is one of the five legendary pit fighters from Onslaught. They all cost six mana total, three colorless and 3 of one color. They are:  
[Jareth, Leonine Titan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jareth, Leonine Titan), [Arcanis the Omnipotent](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Arcanis the Omnipotent), [Visara the Dreadful](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Visara the Dreadful), [Rorix Bladewing](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rorix Bladewing), and [Silvos, Rogue Elemental](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Silvos, Rogue Elemental)
posts.html:

Posted By: Skeletextman (10/31/2012 1:32:37 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
There are various scenarios where you shouldn't play this as if it had a "hidden cost."  
  
For instance, against a control deck with removal like Wrath of God, Oblivion Ring, and Swords to Plowshares, the regeneration is irrelevant and you might as well try to get him to stick if you can.   
  
Against a red deck, it's probably worth it to play him as soon as you can and force your opponent to 2-for-1 himself if he wants to remove Silvos.   
  
If you're always thinking you have to wait to play this until you have seven mana, you're making the card worse than it is. You just need to know what kind of deck you're playing against.
posts.html:
There are various scenarios where you shouldn't play this as if it had a "hidden cost."

For instance, against a control deck with removal like Wrath of God, Oblivion Ring, and Swords to Plowshares, the regeneration is irrelevant and you might as well try to get him to stick if you can.

Against a red deck, it's probably worth it to play him as soon as you can and force your opponent to 2-for-1 himself if he wants to remove Silvos.

If you're always thinking you have to wait to play this until you have seven mana, you're making the card worse than it is. You just need to know what kind of deck you're playing against.
